The Buddha, with his Dharma eye, saw this from afar. He transformed into a tree spirit, half of his body human, and scolded him, saying:

Then the World-Honored One manifested a divine light image and spoke a verse, saying:

The body is foremost, always striving to learn. Benevolence can teach others, without slacking off, then one becomes wise.
Learning first corrects oneself, and then corrects others. Regulating the body and entering wisdom, one will surely ascend to the highest rank.

When Mahallaka saw the Buddha's manifested body and radiance, he was filled with grief and joy. He trembled and bowed at the Buddha's feet. The minds of the assembly were filled with resentment and wonder at the reason for this. Each of them guarded the king's intentions and did not dare to rebuke him, thinking of his foolishness and obscurity in not understanding the distribution of alms, and their minds were weary.

Chapter 21: Worldly Affairs Dharmapada Parable Sutra, Chapter 21: Worldly Affairs In the past, there was a Brahman king named Duoweixie. The king served the ninety-six kinds of non-Buddhist paths.

One day, the king suddenly gave rise to a good thought and wanted to make great offerings, according to the Brahman method. He piled up treasures like mountains and used them for offerings. If there were beggars, he allowed them to take a handful of heavy [treasures] and leave. In this way, for several days, the pile did not decrease.
The Buddha knew that this king's past merits should be saved, so he transformed into a brahman and went to his country.
The king came out to greet him and they exchanged greetings, saying:
What do you seek?
Do not hesitate.
The brahman replied:
I have come from afar and want to beg for precious treasures to build a house.
The king said:
Excellent!
Take a handful of heavy [treasures] and leave.
The brahman took a handful and walked seven steps, then returned it to its original place.
The king asked:
Why don't you take it?
The brahman replied:
This is just enough to build a house. I will also need to take a wife. It is not enough for both purposes, so I do not take it.
The king said:
Take three more handfuls.
The brahman then took them,
walked seven steps, and put them back in their original place.
The king asked the brahman:
Why do you do this again?
He replied:
This is enough to take a wife, but I do not have fields, servants, cattle, or horses. It is still not enough, so I stop.
The king said:
Take seven more handfuls.
The brahman then took them, walked seven steps, and put them back in their original place.
The king said:
What is the meaning of this again?
The brahman replied:
If I have sons and daughters, I will need to marry them off. The expenses for auspicious and inauspicious events are not enough, so I do not take them.
The king said:
I have accumulated treasures and wish to offer them to you.
The brahman accepted them and left.
The king greatly wondered and asked the reason again.
The brahman replied:

Originally, I was begging to use for living. Thinking carefully, human life in the world is not long. All things are impermanent, and it is difficult to protect from day to night. The causes and conditions eventually become heavy, and the suffering deepens day by day. Accumulating treasures like mountains does not benefit oneself. Greed and desire only bring hardship to oneself. It is better to stop the mind and seek the path of non-action. Therefore, I did not accept them.

Formerly the Buddha was in a monastery in the country of Shravasti. At that time, there were four bhikshus sitting under a tree, discussing among themselves:

One person said:

One person said:
There is nothing more suffering in the world than anger.
One person said:
There is nothing more suffering in the world than hunger and thirst.
One person said:
There is nothing more suffering in the world than fear.
They argued about the meaning of suffering and would not stop.
The Buddha knew what they were saying and went to their place. He asked the bhikshus:

He then rose, bowed, and fully related what they had discussed.
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

The body is the root of various sufferings, the source of calamities and misfortunes. It exhausts the mind, strains the thoughts, and brings about myriad worries. Beings in the three realms move and struggle, harming and robbing each other. The bondage of self-attachment does not cease, all due to the body.

If one wishes to leave worldly suffering, one should seek quiescence and cessation. Concentrating the mind, guarding the true, and being still without thought, one can attain nirvÄá¹‡a, which is the utmost bliss.
Thereupon, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:

There is no bliss in minor bliss, minor eloquence, or minor wisdom. Those who seek the great by observing and inquiring will attain great peace.
I am the World-Honored One, eternally free from worry, rightly crossing the three existences, alone subduing the many demons.
After the Buddha spoke the verse, he told the bhiká¹£us:

At that time, there were four animals that relied on him and always found peace:

One night, the four animals asked each other:
What is the greatest suffering in the world?
The crow said:

Hunger and thirst are the greatest suffering. When hungry and thirsty, the body becomes emaciated, the eyes dim, and the spirit is restless. One may throw oneself into a net or not care about sharp blades. We lose our lives because of this. From this perspective, hunger and thirst are suffering.
The dove said:
'Sexual desire is the most painful. When lustful desires are rampant, one has no regard for anything. The danger of losing one's body and life all comes from this.'
The poisonous snake said:
'Anger is the most painful. When a poisonous thought arises, one does not avoid close or distant. It can also kill people and also kill oneself.'
The deer said:

'Fear is the most painful. When I roam the forest, my heart is always apprehensive, fearing hunters and jackals. At the slightest sound, I rush to the edge of a pit or cliff, abandoning my mother and child, with a trembling heart. Based on this, fear is suffering.'
The bhiká¹£u heard this and said to them:
'What you are discussing is just the branches, not the root of suffering.

In the world, there is no suffering greater than having a body. The body is an instrument of suffering, with immeasurable worries and fears. For this reason, I have left the mundane world to study the Way, to extinguish thoughts and cut off desires, not coveting the four elements, wanting to cut off the root of suffering and aspire to nirvana.'
The path to nirvana is tranquil extinction without form, with worries and troubles forever ended, and then there is great peace.
The four birds heard this and their minds immediately opened up and understood.

At that time, the bhiká¹£u with the five supernatural powers was me.

The bhiká¹£us, upon hearing this, were ashamed and reproached themselves, and then attained the path of arhatship in the Buddha's presence.
Chapter 24: Good Joy, Fascicle on Dharma Phrases and Parables, Chapter 24 on Good Joy. In the past, the Buddha was in a monastery in Shravasti.
At that time, there were four newly ordained bhiká¹£us who went together to sit in meditation under a mango tree. The mango flowers were luxuriant, colorful, and fragrant. They said to each other:
Among the myriad things in the world, which is most lovable and pleasing to the human mind?
One person said:
In the second month of spring, the trees are lush and in full bloom. Amusing oneself in the fields, this is the greatest joy.
One person said:
A prosperous gathering of relatives, toasting and mingling, with music and singing and dancing, this is the greatest joy.
One person said:

Accumulating wealth and getting whatever one desires, with carriages, horses, and clothing unlike those of the common people, entering and leaving with radiance, attracting the attention of passersby, this is the greatest joy.
One person said:
Having beautiful wives and concubines, with colorful clothing and fragrant scents, indulging in desires to one's heart's content, this is the greatest joy.

The Buddha knew that the four people were suitable to be guided and liberated, but their minds were running after the six desires, not contemplating impermanence. He immediately called the four people and asked them:
What were you discussing while sitting under the tree just now?
The four people truthfully told him what they enjoyed.
The Buddha told the four people:
What you have discussed are all paths of worry, fear, and ruin, not the Dharma of eternal peace and supreme bliss.

All things flourish in spring, but wither in autumn and winter. Family and relatives gather in joy, but will all part ways. Wealth, treasures, carriages, horses, and the five kinds of property are divided among the five families. Wives and beautiful women are the masters of love and hatred.

Ordinary people in the world create resentment and misfortune, endangering their bodies and destroying their clans with immeasurable worries and fears. The sufferings of the three evil paths and the eight difficulties are all due to this.
Therefore, bhiká¹£us abandon the world and seek the Way. Their aspiration lies in non-action, not greedy for fame and profit. Attaining nirvÄá¹‡a is the supreme bliss.
Then the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Love and joy give rise to sorrow, love and joy give rise to fear. Without anything to love and enjoy,
what sorrow and what fear?
Fondness gives rise to sorrow, fondness gives rise to fear. Without anything to be fond of, what sorrow and what fear?
Greed gives rise to worry, greed gives rise to fear. Understanding the absence of greed, what worry is there, what fear?
The Dharma of greed is accomplished through precepts, sincerity, and shame. Practicing close to the Way,
one is loved by the multitude.
If desires do not arise, and one speaks only after careful thought, with a mind free from greed, one will surely cross the stream.
The Buddha said to the four monks:

In the past, there was a king named Universal Peace, who was close friends with the four kings of neighboring countries. He invited the four kings to a banquet for a month, with food and entertainment beyond compare.
On the day of their departure, King Universal Peace asked the four kings:
'What do people in the world consider to be happiness?'
One king said:
'Play is happiness.'
Another king said:
'The music of family gatherings is happiness.'
Another king said:
'Accumulating wealth and having everything one desires is happiness.'
One king said:
'The greatest pleasure is indulging in desires as one pleases.'
King Universal Peace said:
'What you are discussing is the root of suffering and the source of worries and fears. Pleasure comes before suffering, and worries and sorrows arise from this.
It is not as good as tranquility, without seeking and without desires, being simple and guarding the One, attaining the Way is bliss.'
The four kings heard this and joyfully believed and understood.
The Buddha told the four monks:
At that time, King Universal Peace was me.
